instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
I have this board for repair with water damage. All cleaned and the ugly parts exchanged. Now i get the following components very hot when i put 3 volts on them :

<CAPACITOR>C2901</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C3101</CAPACITOR>

<CAPACITOR>C2300</CAPACITOR>

as well as the RAM blocks.

Any suggestions? PP3V42 ist present and stable, i have green light as well. F7040 is shorted on PIN2, that where i put 3V on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: Sounds to me like a shorted high side FET on the memory power bus <TRANSISTOR>Q7330</TRANSISTOR>. I'm afraid that will have done terminal damage to MCP/RAM and more.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
it is absolutely shorted, i recognized it by burning my finger.

Where can i find the specs to this part?
I would like to change and give it a try.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
This board is toast....waste of time.
But if you must, <CHIP>U7300</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7330</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7335</TRANSISTOR> should all be changed together. Source from scrap board...Any board that has a <CHIP>TPS51116</CHIP> on it, you can then also take the FETs if they are the same size. Exact part numbers are not critical on the FETs.
Actually measure resistance to GND on the <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> bus, anything under 17K will also be a dead MCP89 and also make it instant death.
